Award.AwardTitle: Expanding E2Coach: Using Actionable Intelligence to Enhance Student Success in Introductory Statistics Courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The modern world is awash in data, greatly amplifying the necessity of statistics education. Introductory statistics courses are often both large and populated by students from a diverse array of backgrounds. Tailoring what is said to these students with an awareness of their interests and goals and an understanding of their background and progress can substantially improve their learning experience. This is true for all students - from those likely to struggle to those who most easily master the material.

For this project, learning analytics techniques are being used to drive personalized instruction for each of the 1400 students who take Stats 250 each term at the University of Michigan. A detailed portrait of the student's background, interests and goals is being created as well as a real-time state of each student's academic progress by collating the rich array of data captured from student work in the LectureTools active learning environment. Given these portraits, the E2Coach system is using computer tailored communication technology to individually address each student and enabling interaction with the student as if they sat down with the instructional team for the course for an expert coaching session.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Students in introductory statistics courses are diverse along many dimensions, yet we traditionally ask them to learn using a single generic approach. They all read the same texts, hear the same lectures, do the same homework and class assignments, get the same advice, and are assessed using the same exams. We have worked hard at the University of Michigan to design classes which optimize learning for the typical student. After years of effort from award-winning instructors our current course, Stats 250, is excellent in the mean. But we had done little to adjust our learning environments to meet the various and specific needs of individual students.

We can do better now. Institutional data repositories and survey technology allow us to assemble a rich portrait of each student, including information about their background, preparation, goals, interests, and affect. Online textbooks, homework systems, discussion forums, and in class questioning provide a real-time portrait of student engagement and conceptual understanding. Predictive models of student performance can be generated by applying learning analytics to historical data. We can anticipate outcomes – crudely at the start of a class and with increasing precision as the term progresses.

This is actionable intelligence. Once we know who each student is, where they’re coming from, what they care about, what they’re doing right now, and where they’re likely headed, we can do something about it – we can provide the advice and support each student needs. But the problem of scale remains. In a course which enrolls 1400 students per term, having the information is not enough: we must build the capacity to act.

Computer tailored communication techniques are well established in the world of public health, where their ability to help large, diverse groups of individuals achieve challenging goals has been extensively tested. Here at the University of Michigan we have implemented the first major application of these tools to education, launching a personalized coaching system called E2Coach.

In the course of this grant, we adapted an original E2Coach tool built for physics courses to support our statistics class. During the summer of 2013, we developed our first statistics coach, developing a system which provides completely personalized support to all of the 1700 - 2200 students who take this course each term. Each student receives feedback, encouragement, and advice which is personalized; aware of their background, interests, goals, and current course status. In addition to tailoring the advice students receive, the system also tailors the voices they here - presenting much of its content in the form of testimonials coming from identity salient peers, along with their faculty and graduate student instructors. Example screens from the Stats 250 E2Coach application can be seen in the four attached images.

During the two year term of this grant, we gradually improved the our coaching content, responding to the needs and interests of students, providing access to practice tools, advice about how to study, organizational support through 'get-things-done' lists, and normative information about how student behavior has affected performance in the past. Student participation in this opt-in system was quite high - over 80% - and their review comments were very positive.

To investigate the impact of the system on student outcomes, we compared student success using the system to expectations developed using data from students who didn't use the system. This allows us to measure performance relative to expectations which account for many student properties, including prior classroom performance.
